content.text: Chart Demo
Here we give some simple examples of using the Chart Module.
The code below requires the Chart web module, which can be viewed in the libraries folder in the left panel.
Sample Data
This section includes some data we will plot.
Endpoint Counts Map
This is endpoint request counts from a web server.
Paired Numeric Coordinate Arrays
Here we generate a series of angle values, and then calculate the
sin()
of each value.
Population Information Array
This is an array of objects containing population data.
Chart Examples
Endpoint Counts Bar Chart
Here we make a bar chart of the endpoint counts data.
We add a single data series. We choose the format
Data Map
since our data is a single map of keys to values we want to plot.
There are two optional fields we have left unfilled:

X Category Array - These are the columns in the bar chart. For Data Map input we can leave this blank because the columns are already specified in the data. (On the other hand we can also include this array, in which case the chart will show exactly the categories specified in the X category array, in that order)

Y Accessor - This is an expression to read data from our data map. We would use this if the values in the map were a structure rather than the simple numbers we want to plot. We will illustrate the use of an accessor below.
Sine and Cosine Waves
Here we plot our generated sine wave.
Here we selected a
line
chart. This gives us two options,
category
data, where each point belongs to a bucket, and
numeric
data, where each x value is a number. Here we have numeric data
We added two data series. We selected the data format option X Array and Y Array, since that is what our input data is.
In this case, we also added a label for each series.
Population Chart
Here we chart our population data.
Here we again select a line chart. This time we have category data. We generate an array of categories below, which is the corresponding age for the population values we will plot.
We add two data series, one for males and one for females.

The elements of our data array are JSON objects, rather than simple numeric values. Here we can define an accessor to get the values we want to plot. We can type a simple function into that line of the form, or we can use the name of a function we defined elsewhere on the page. (These fields are javascript expressions, so what we are entering is javscript code. For example the name of a cell is a javascript variable, just as we would use in a formula.)
Using accessors is very convenient. We don't have to create a new cell just to store the values we want to plot. Too bad we couldn't do that for the x categories! (That will be fixed later.)
In the chart we also added a few settings - the title, the series names and we choose not to show the points on our lines.
Here is the cell defining out "categories":
